a.g: O you who have believed, be persistently standing firm for Allah, witnesses in justice, and do not let the hatred of a people prevent you from being just. Be just; that is nearer to righteousness. And fear Allah; indeed, Allah is Acquainted with what you do.
Allah has promised those who believe and do righteous deeds [that] for them there is forgiveness and great reward.
But those who disbelieve and deny Our signs - those are the companions of Hellfire.

O you who have believed, remember the favor of Allah upon you when a people determined to extend their hands [in aggression] against you, but He withheld their hands from you; and fear Allah. And upon Allah let the believers rely.

And Allah had already taken a covenant from the Children of Israel, and We delegated from among them twelve leaders. And Allah said, "I am with you. If you establish prayer and give zakah and believe in My messengers and support them and loan Allah a goodly loan, I will surely remove from you your misdeeds and admit you to gardens beneath which rivers flow. But whoever of you disbelieves after that has certainly strayed from the soundness of the way."

So for their breaking of the covenant We cursed them and made their hearts hard. They distort words from their [proper] usages and have forgotten a portion of that of which they were reminded. And you will still observe deceit among them, except a few of them. But pardon them and overlook [their misdeeds]. Indeed, Allah loves the doers of good.

Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol 2: The Lawful and Prohibited
And why do I imagine this when what I imagine has already occurred? For indeed, Allah sent our Prophet (peace be upon him) upon a gap (fatra) from the messengers, and the law (shar') of Jesus (peace be upon him) had passed nearly six hundred years ago. The people were divided into those who denied him from the Jews and idol worshippers, and into those who believed in him, but corruption (fisq) had spread among them as it has spread in our time now. The disbelievers (kuffar) were addressed with the branches of the law (shari'a), and the wealth (amwal) was in the hands of those who denied him and those who believed. As for the deniers, they were dealing without the law of Jesus (peace be upon him), and as for the believers, they were lax with the foundation of belief (tasdiq) just as Muslims are lax now, even though the era of prophethood was closer. Thus, all the wealth, or most of it, or much of it, was unlawful (haram) (peace be upon him), and he pardoned what had passed and did not interfere with it, and he specified the owners of the hands with the wealth, and he established the law (shar'). And what was established as unlawful (tahrim) in a law does not become lawful (halal) due to the sending of a messenger, nor does it become lawful by the one who possesses the unlawful surrendering it. For we do not take in the jizya from the people of the covenant (ahl al-dhimma) what we specifically know to be the price of wine or usurious wealth (riba). Indeed, their wealth at that time was like our wealth now, and the matter of the Arabs was more severe due to the prevalence of plunder and raids among them. So it became clear that the fourth probability is definitive in the legal opinion (fatwa), and the fifth probability is the path of piety (wara'), indeed, complete piety (wara') is restricting oneself in the permissible (mubah) to the measure of need (haja) and abandoning expansion in the worldly life (dunya) entirely, and that is the path of the hereafter (akhira).

And it is said: 'As if he killed all people.' And from Ali, may Allah be pleased with him: 'Whoever hoards food for forty days, his heart (Qalb) hardens.' And from him also: 'He burned the food of a hoarder with fire.' And it is narrated regarding the virtue of abandoning hoarding from him, peace and blessings be upon him: 'Whoever brings food and sells it at the price of its day, it is as if he gave it in charity (Sadaqah).' And in another wording: 'It is as if he freed a slave (Raqabah).' The hadith: 'Whoever brings food and sells it at the price of its day, it is as if he gave it in charity (Sadaqah).' And in another wording: 'It is as if he freed a slave (Raqabah).' Ibn Mardawayh in the Tafsir narrated it from the hadith of Ibn Mas'ud with a weak chain. 'There is no one who brings food to a town from the towns of the Muslims and sells it at the price of its day except that his status with Allah is like the status of a martyr (Shahid).' And Al-Hakim from the hadith of Al-Yasa' ibn Al-Mughirah: 'Indeed, the one who brings to a market is like a Mujahid (one who strives) in the path of Allah.' And it is disconnected. And it is said regarding His saying, the Exalted: 'And whoever intends therein deviation with injustice, We will make him taste of a painful punishment.' Indeed, hoarding is from injustice (Zulm) and falls under it in the threat.

a.g: Indeed, the penalty for those who wage war against Allah and His Messenger and strive upon earth [to cause] corruption is none but that they be killed or crucified or that their hands and feet be cut off from opposite sides or that they be exiled from the land. That is for them a disgrace in this world; and for them in the Hereafter is a great punishment,
Except for those who return [repenting] before you apprehend them. And know that Allah is Forgiving and Merciful.
O you who have believed, fear Allah and seek the means [of nearness] to Him and strive in His cause that you may succeed.

Indeed, those who disbelieve - if they should have all that is in the earth and the like of it with it by which to ransom themselves from the punishment of the Day of Resurrection, it will not be accepted from them, and for them is a painful punishment
They will wish to get out of the Fire, but never are they to emerge therefrom, and for them is an enduring punishment.
[As for] the thief, the male and the female, amputate their hands in recompense for what they committed as a deterrent [punishment] from Allah. And Allah is Exalted in Might and Wise.
But whoever repents after his wrongdoing and reforms, indeed, Allah will turn to him in forgiveness. Indeed, Allah is Forgiving and Merciful.
Do you not know that to Allah belongs the dominion of the heavens and the earth? He punishes whom He wills and forgives whom He wills, and Allah is over all things competent.

O Messenger, let them not grieve you who hasten into disbelief of those who say, "We believe" with their mouths, but their hearts believe not, and from among the Jews. [They are] avid listeners to falsehood, listening to another people who have not come to you. They distort words beyond their [proper] usages, saying "If you are given this, take it; but if you are not given it, then beware." But he for whom Allah intends fitnah - never will you possess [power to do] for him a thing against Allah. Those are the ones for whom Allah does not intend to purify their hearts. For them in this world is disgrace, and for them in the Hereafter is a great punishment.

[They are] avid listeners to falsehood, devourers of [what is] unlawful. So if they come to you, [O Muhammad], judge between them or turn away from them. And if you turn away from them - never will they harm you at all. And if you judge, judge between them with justice. Indeed, Allah loves those who act justly.

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Secrets of Fasting
Third: Restraining the hearing from listening to every disliked thing because everything whose speech is forbidden, listening to it is also forbidden. Therefore, Allah the Exalted equated between the listener and the consumer of unlawful gain (Suhut) when He said: 'They are listeners to falsehood, consumers of unlawful gain (Suhut)' (Quran 5:42). And He the Exalted said: 'If only the rabbis and the scholars had forbidden them from their sinful speech and consumption of unlawful gain (Suhut)' (Quran 5:63). So remaining silent about backbiting is forbidden. And He said: 'Indeed, you then are like them' (Quran 4:140). Therefore, the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: 'The backbiter and the listener are partners in sin' (Hadith 22).

a.g: But how is it that they come to you for judgement while they have the Torah, in which is the judgement of Allah? Then they turn away, [even] after that; but those are not [in fact] believers.

Indeed, We sent down the Torah, in which was guidance and light. The prophets who submitted [to Allah] judged by it for the Jews, as did the rabbis and scholars by that with which they were entrusted of the Scripture of Allah, and they were witnesses thereto. So do not fear the people but fear Me, and do not exchange My verses for a small price. And whoever does not judge by what Allah has revealed - then it is those who are the disbelievers.

And We ordained for them therein a life for a life, an eye for an eye, a nose for a nose, an ear for an ear, a tooth for a tooth, and for wounds is legal retribution. But whoever gives [up his right as] charity, it is an expiation for him. And whoever does not judge by what Allah has revealed - then it is those who are the wrongdoers.

And We sent, following in their footsteps, Jesus, the son of Mary, confirming that which came before him in the Torah; and We gave him the Gospel, in which was guidance and light and confirming that which preceded it of the Torah as guidance and instruction for the righteous.
And let the People of the Gospel judge by what Allah has revealed therein. And whoever does not judge by what Allah has revealed - then it is those who are the defiantly disobedient.

And We have revealed to you, [O Muhammad], the Book in truth, confirming that which preceded it of the Scripture and as a criterion over it. So judge between them by what Allah has revealed and do not follow their inclinations away from what has come to you of the truth. To each of you We prescribed a law and a method. Had Allah willed, He would have made you one nation [united in religion], but [He intended] to test you in what He has given you; so race to [all that is] good. To Allah is your return all together, and He will [then] inform you concerning that over which you used to differ.

And judge, [O Muhammad], between them by what Allah has revealed and do not follow their inclinations and beware of them, lest they tempt you away from some of what Allah has revealed to you. And if they turn away - then know that Allah only intends to afflict them with some of their [own] sins. And indeed, many among the people are defiantly disobedient.
Then is it the judgement of [the time of] ignorance they desire? But who is better than Allah in judgement for a people who are certain [in faith].

O you who have believed, do not take the Jews and the Christians as allies. They are [in fact] allies of one another. And whoever is an ally to them among you - then indeed, he is [one] of them. Indeed, Allah guides not the wrongdoing people.

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Love, Longing, and Intimacy
As for hating the disbelievers (Kuffar), rejecting them, and despising them, what has come regarding this from evidences of the Quran and reports (Akhbar) is innumerable, such as His saying, the Exalted: "Let not the believers take the disbelievers as allies (Awliya) instead of the believers." And He said, the Exalted: "O you who have believed, do not take the Jews and the Christians as allies (Awliya)." And He said, the Exalted: "And thus We make some of the wrongdoers allies (Nuwalli) of others." And in the report (Khabar): "Indeed, Allah, the Exalted, took the covenant (Mithaq) upon every believer to hate every hypocrite (Munafiq) and upon every hypocrite (Munafiq) to hate every believer." And he, peace be upon him, said: "A person is with whom he loves." And he said: "Whoever loves a people and allies with them (Walahum) will be gathered with them on the Day of Resurrection." And he, peace be upon him, said: "The firmest bond of faith (Iman) is love for the sake of Allah (Al-Hubb fi Allah) and hatred for the sake of Allah (Al-Bughd fi Allah)." The evidences for this we have already mentioned in the explanation of love and hatred for the sake of Allah, the Exalted, from the Book of the Etiquettes of Companionship (Adab al-Suhba), and in the Book of Commanding Good and Forbidding Evil (Al-Amr bi al-Ma'ruf wa al-Nahy 'an al-Munkar); so we do not repeat it.

a.g: So you see those in whose hearts is disease hastening into [association with] them, saying, "We are afraid a misfortune may strike us." But perhaps Allah will bring conquest or a decision from Him, and they will become, over what they have been concealing within themselves, regretful.
And those who believe will say, "Are these the ones who swore by Allah their strongest oaths that indeed they were with you?" Their deeds have become worthless, and they have become losers.

O you who have believed, whoever of you should revert from his religion - Allah will bring forth [in place of them] a people He will love and who will love Him [who are] humble toward the believers, powerful against the disbelievers; they strive in the cause of Allah and do not fear the blame of a critic. That is the favor of Allah; He bestows it upon whom He wills. And Allah is all-Encompassing and Knowing.

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Pride and Conceit
Indeed, know that the evidences of the Quran are manifest in showing that God, the Exalted, loves His servant, so it is necessary to know the meaning of that. Let us first present the evidences for His love, for God, the Exalted, has said: "He loves them and they love Him." And love [mahabba], in the convention of language, is an expression for the inclination of the soul [nafs] towards what is agreeable and suitable. This is only conceivable for a deficient soul, for it is that which, when something agreeable to it is attained, it gains a perfection thereby and delights in attaining it. This is impossible for God, the Exalted, for every perfection [kamal], beauty [jamal], splendor [baha'], and majesty [jalal] possible for the Divine Reality is present, realized, and necessarily realized eternally and pre-eternally. Its renewal or its removal is inconceivable. Therefore, He has no regard for other than Him inasmuch as it is other than Him. Rather, His regard is only for His Essence and His acts. And there is nothing in existence except His Essence and His acts. For this reason, when the verse of God, the Exalted, "He loves them and they love Him" was recited to the Shaykh Abu Sa'id al-Mihani, may God have mercy on him, he said: "Rightly does He love them, for He loves nothing but His own Self," meaning that He is the All and that there is nothing in existence other than Him. So, for One who loves nothing but His own Self, the acts of His Self, and the compositions of His Self, His love does not transcend His Essence and the concomitants of His Essence inasmuch as they are related to His Essence. He, therefore, loves nothing but His own Self. And what has come in the expressions concerning His love for His servants is interpreted, and its meaning returns to the lifting of the veil [hijab] from his heart [qalb] so that he may see Him with his heart, and to enabling him to attain proximity [qurb] to Him, and to His willing that for him in pre-eternity. Thus, His love for whom He loves is pre-eternal whenever it is attributed to the pre-eternal will [irada] which necessitated enabling this servant to traverse the paths of this proximity. And when it is attributed to His act which lifts the veil from the heart of His servant, it is a temporally originated thing that occurs with the occurrence of the cause necessitating it, as God, the Exalted, has said: "My servant does not cease drawing near to Me through supererogatory acts until I love him." Thus, his drawing near through supererogatory acts becomes a cause for the purity of his inner being, the raising of the veil from his heart, and his attainment of the station of proximity to his Lord. All of that is the act of God, the Exalted, and His gentleness towards him, and that is the meaning of His love. This is only understood by an example: A king may bring his servant close to himself and permit him to be present in his court at all times due to the king's inclination towards him, either to be aided by his strength, or to find comfort in seeing him, or to consult him for his opinion, or to prepare the means for his food and drink. It is then said: "The king loves him," and its meaning is the king's inclination towards him for what is in him of a meaning agreeable and suitable to him. And a king may bring a servant close and not prevent him from entering upon him, not for benefiting from him, nor for seeking his aid, but because the servant in himself is described with praiseworthy morals [akhlaq] and noble qualities [khisal] that befit him to be close to the presence of the king and to have a great share of his proximity, while the king has no interest in him whatsoever. So, when the king lifts the veil between himself and him, it is said: "He has loved him." And when the servant acquires from the noble qualities what necessitates the lifting of the veil, it is said: "He has found a means and endeared himself to the king." So, the love of God for the servant is only according to the second meaning, not the first. And it is only valid to liken it to the second meaning on the condition that the notion of change occurring in Him with the origination of proximity does not enter your understanding. For the beloved [habib] is the one close [qarib] to God, the Exalted. And proximity to God lies in remoteness from the attributes of beasts, predators, and devils, and in adorning oneself with noble morals [makarim al-akhlaq] which are the divine morals [al-akhlaq al-ilahiyya]. Thus, it is a proximity by attribute [sifa], not by place [makan]. And whoever was not close and then became close has changed. Perhaps one might think from this that when proximity originated, the attribute of both the servant and the Lord changed, since He became close after not being close, and this is impossible for God, the Exalted, for change in Him is impossible. Rather, He remains ever in the attributes of perfection [kamal] and majesty [jalal] as He was in the pre-eternity of pre-eternities. This is only unveiled by an example concerning proximity between persons: Two persons may draw close by both of them moving, or one may be stationary and the other moves, and proximity is achieved by a change in one of them without change in the other. Indeed, proximity in attributes is also like this: The student seeks proximity to the degree of his teacher in the perfection [kamal] and beauty [jamal] of knowledge, while the teacher is fixed in the perfection of his knowledge, not moving by descending to the degree of his student; the student is the one who moves.

He returned to them and informed them of what the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said, and they said: 'We are pleased, we are pleased.' This indicates that His saying: "That is the bounty of Allah which He gives to whom He wills" means the increased reward of the poor in their remembrance (Dhikr). As for His saying: "O you who have believed, whoever among you turns back from his religion - Allah will bring forth a people He will love and who will love Him, humble (Adhillah) toward the believers, mighty (A'izzah) against the disbelievers; they strive in the cause of Allah and do not fear the blame of a critic. That is the bounty of Allah which He gives to whom He wills. And Allah is all-Encompassing and Knowing." It is in another meaning, which is that when Allah the Exalted wills to replace a people with another people, He replaces them with a people whom He loves and who love Him, and He makes them humble (Adhillah) toward the believers, mighty (A'izzah) against the disbelievers, not fearing in Allah the blame of a critic, and that is the bounty of Allah which He gives to whom He wills, and Allah is all-Encompassing and Knowing.

As for his saying: Indeed, richness is an attribute of the Truth (Al-Haqq), some shaykhs answered him by saying: Do you see that Allah the Exalted is rich through causes and accidents? He fell silent and did not speak. Others answered by saying: Indeed, arrogance is from the attributes of the Truth, so it should be better than humility. Then they said: Rather, this indicates that poverty is better because the attributes of servitude (al-'ubudiyyah) are a favor for the servant (al-'abd) like fear (al-khawf) and hope (al-raja'), and the attributes of lordship (al-rububiyyah) should not be contended over. Therefore, Allah the Exalted said in what was narrated from our Prophet, peace be upon him: "Pride (al-kibriya') is My cloak and majesty (al-'azamah) is My garment, so whoever contends with Me in one of them, I will break him." And Sahl said: Love of honor (al-'izz) and permanence (al-baqa') is polytheism (shirk) in lordship and contention in it because they are from the attributes of the Lord, the Exalted. a.g: Your ally is none but Allah and [therefore] His Messenger and those who have believed - those who establish prayer and give zakah, and they bow [in worship].
And whoever is an ally of Allah and His Messenger and those who have believed - indeed, the party of Allah - they will be the predominant.

O you who have believed, take not those who have taken your religion in ridicule and amusement among the ones who were given the Scripture before you nor the disbelievers as allies. And fear Allah, if you should [truly] be believers.
And when you call to prayer, they take it in ridicule and amusement. That is because they are a people who do not use reason.

Say, "O People of the Scripture, do you resent us except [for the fact] that we have believed in Allah and what was revealed to us and what was revealed before and because most of you are defiantly disobedient?"

Say, "Shall I inform you of [what is] worse than that as penalty from Allah? [It is that of] those whom Allah has cursed and with whom He became angry and made of them apes and pigs and slaves of Taghut. Those are worse in position and further astray from the sound way."

And when they come to you, they say, "We believe." But they have entered with disbelief [in their hearts], and they have certainly left with it. And Allah is most knowing of what they were concealing.
And you see many of them hastening into sin and aggression and the devouring of [what is] unlawful. How wretched is what they have been doing.
Why do the rabbis and religious scholars not forbid them from saying what is sinful and devouring what is unlawful? How wretched is what they have been practicing.

a.g: And the Jews say, "The hand of Allah is chained." Chained are their hands, and cursed are they for what they say. Rather, both His hands are extended; He spends however He wills. And that which has been revealed to you from your Lord will surely increase many of them in transgression and disbelief. And We have cast among them animosity and hatred until the Day of Resurrection. Every time they kindled the fire of war [against you], Allah extinguished it. And they strive throughout the land [causing] corruption, and Allah does not like corrupters.
And if only the People of the Scripture had believed and feared Allah, We would have removed from them their misdeeds and admitted them to Gardens of Pleasure.

And if only they upheld [the law of] the Torah, the Gospel, and what has been revealed to them from their Lord, they would have consumed [provision] from above them and from beneath their feet. Among them are a moderate community, but many of them - evil is that which they do.

O Messenger, announce that which has been revealed to you from your Lord, and if you do not, then you have not conveyed His message. And Allah will protect you from the people. Indeed, Allah does not guide the disbelieving people.

Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol 4: Watchfulness and Self-Examination
Therefore, it is concluded for every possessor of determination who believes in Allah and the Last Day that he should not neglect accounting his Soul (Nafs) and constraining it in its movements, stillness, fleeting thoughts, and steps. For every breath of life is a precious jewel with no substitute, through which can be purchased a treasure of treasures whose bliss is endless for all eternity. The contraction of these breaths wasted or diverted to what brings destruction is a great, tremendous loss that no rational Soul (Nafs) would permit. When the servant (Abd) awakens and completes the obligatory morning prayer (Fajr), he should empty his Heart (Qalb) for an hour to contract with his Soul (Nafs), just as a merchant, when delivering goods to the working partner, empties the council for contracting with him. He says to the Soul (Nafs): 'I have no merchandise except life; whenever it perishes, the capital has perished, and despair occurs regarding trade and seeking profit. This new day, Allah has granted me respite in it, postponed my term, and bestowed favor upon me. If He had taken me, I would wish to be returned to the world for a single day to perform righteous deeds in it. Consider that you have died and then been returned. Beware, then beware, of wasting this day, for every breath of the breaths is a jewel of no value. And know, O Soul (Nafs), that the day and night are twenty-four hours, and it has been reported in the tradition that for every day and night, twenty-four treasuries are spread out for the servant, so one of them is opened for him, and he sees it filled with light from his good deeds that he performed in that hour.'

a.g: We had already taken the covenant of the Children of Israel and had sent to them messengers. Whenever there came to them a messenger with what their souls did not desire, a party [of messengers] they denied, and another party they killed.

And they thought there would be no [resulting] punishment, so they became blind and deaf. Then Allah turned to them in forgiveness; then [again] many of them became blind and deaf. And Allah is Seeing of what they do.

They have certainly disbelieved who say, "Allah is the Messiah, the son of Mary" while the Messiah has said, "O Children of Israel, worship Allah, my Lord and your Lord." Indeed, he who associates others with Allah - Allah has forbidden him Paradise, and his refuge is the Fire. And there are not for the wrongdoers any helpers.

They have certainly disbelieved who say, "Allah is the third of three." And there is no god except one God. And if they do not desist from what they are saying, there will surely afflict the disbelievers among them a painful punishment.
So will they not repent to Allah and seek His forgiveness? And Allah is Forgiving and Merciful.

The Messiah, son of Mary, was not but a messenger; [other] messengers have passed on before him. And his mother was a supporter of truth. They both used to eat food. Look how We make clear to them the signs; then look how they are deluded.
Say, "Do you worship besides Allah that which holds for you no [power of] harm or benefit while it is Allah who is the Hearing, the Knowing?"

Say, "O People of the Scripture, do not exceed limits in your religion beyond the truth and do not follow the inclinations of a people who had gone astray before and misled many and have strayed from the soundness of the way."
Cursed were those who disbelieved among the Children of Israel by the tongue of David and of Jesus, the son of Mary. That was because they disobeyed and [habitually] transgressed.

Vol 2: Etiquette of Eating
And Al-Hasan ibn Ali (may Allah be pleased with them both) passed by a group of the poor (Masakin) who ask people on the road, and they had spread crumbs on the ground in the sand and they were eating, and he was on his mule. He greeted them, and they said to him: 'Come to lunch, O son of the daughter of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him).' He said: 'Yes, indeed Allah does not love the arrogant (Mustakbirin).' And Al-Hasan ibn Ali (may Allah be pleased with them both) would pass by the beggars while they had crumbs before them, and they would say: 'Come to lunch, O son of the Messenger of Allah.' The second aspect is that the one who occupies his Soul (Nafs) with seeking the pleasure of people about him and improving their belief in him is deluded, because if he knew Allah with true knowledge, he would know that the creation cannot avail him anything from Allah, and that his harm and benefit are in the hand of Allah, and there is no benefactor nor harmer except Him, and that whoever seeks the pleasure and love of people with the anger of Allah, Allah will be angry with him and make people angry with him. Rather, the pleasure of people is an unattainable goal, so the pleasure of Allah is more worthy of seeking. Therefore, Al-Shafi'i said to Yunus ibn Abd al-A'la: 'By Allah, I only advise you: there is no way to safety from people, so look at what suits you and do it.' Therefore, it is said: 'Whoever watches people dies grieving, and the bold one attains pleasure.' And Sahl looked at a man from his companions and said to him: 'Do such and such' for something he commanded him, and he said: 'O master, I cannot do it because of people.' So he turned to his companions and said: 'A servant does not attain the reality of this matter until he is in one of two descriptions: a servant from whose eye people have fallen, so he sees in the world only his Creator, and that no one can harm him nor benefit him; and a servant whose Soul (Nafs) has fallen from his Heart (Qalb), so he does not care in what state they see him.' And Al-Shafi'i (may Allah have mercy on him) said: 'There is no one except that he has a lover and a hater, so if it is like this, then be with the people of obedience to Allah.' And it was said to Al-Hasan: 'O Abu Sa'id, there are people who attend your gathering whose aim is only to follow...'

Rather, amusement (Lahw) and idle talk (Laghw) - Allah the Exalted does not hold one accountable for them if what is meant by them is an action that has no benefit. For if a person were to impose upon himself to place his hand on his head one hundred times a day, this is frivolity that has no benefit and is not prohibited. Allah the Exalted said: 'Allah will not call you to account for what is futile in your oaths, but He will call you to account for your deliberate oaths; for expiation, feed ten indigent persons, on a scale of the average for the food of your families; or clothe them; or give a slave his freedom. a.g: O you who have believed, indeed, intoxicants, gambling, [sacrificing on] stone alters [to other than Allah], and divining arrows are but defilement from the work of Satan, so avoid it that you may be successful.
Satan only wants to cause between you animosity and hatred through intoxicants and gambling and to avert you from the remembrance of Allah and from prayer. So will you not desist?
And obey Allah and obey the Messenger and beware. And if you turn away - then know that upon Our Messenger is only [the responsibility for] clear notification.

There is not upon those who believe and do righteousness [any] blame concerning what they have eaten [in the past] if they [now] fear Allah and believe and do righteous deeds, and then fear Allah and believe, and then fear Allah and do good; and Allah loves the doers of good.

O you who have believed, Allah will surely test you through something of the game that your hands and spears [can] reach, that Allah may make evident those who fear Him unseen. And whoever transgresses after that - for him is a painful punishment.

O you who have believed, do not kill game while you are in the state of ihram. And whoever of you kills it intentionally - the penalty is an equivalent from sacrificial animals to what he killed, as judged by two just men among you as an offering [to Allah] delivered to the Ka'bah, or an expiation: the feeding of needy people or the equivalent of that in fasting, that he may taste the consequence of his deed. Allah has pardoned what is past; but whoever returns [to violation], then Allah will take retribution from him. And Allah is Exalted in Might and Owner of Retribution.

Lawful to you is game from the sea and its food as provision for you and the travelers, but forbidden to you is game from the land as long as you are in the state of ihram. And fear Allah to whom you will be gathered.

Allah has made the Ka'bah, the Sacred House, standing for the people and [has sanctified] the sacred months and the sacrificial animals and the garlands [by which they are identified]. That is so you may know that Allah knows what is in the heavens and what is in the earth and that Allah is Knowing of all things.
Know that Allah is severe in penalty and that Allah is Forgiving and Merciful.
Not upon the Messenger is [responsibility] except [for] notification. And Allah knows whatever you reveal and whatever you conceal.
Say, "Not equal are the evil and the good, although the abundance of evil might impress you." So fear Allah, O you of understanding, that you may be successful.

O you who have believed, do not ask about things which, if they are shown to you, will distress you. But if you ask about them while the Qur'an is being revealed, they will be shown to you. Allah has pardoned that which is past; and Allah is Forgiving and Forbearing.

Vol 2: Etiquette of Seclusion
And Abu Bakr (may Allah be pleased with him) stood as a preacher and said: 'O people, you recite this verse: "O you who have believed, upon you is [responsibility for] yourselves (Anfusakum). He who has strayed will not harm you when you have been guided. To Allah is your return all together; then He will inform you of what you used to do." And you place it in other than its proper place. And I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) say: "When people see evil (Al-Munkar) and do not change it, Allah is about to encompass them with punishment." The hadith of Abu Bakr: "You recite this verse: 'O you who have believed, upon you is [responsibility for] yourselves (Anfusakum). He who has strayed will not harm you when you have been guided.' And you indeed place it in other than its proper place." The hadith was reported by the compilers of the Sunan. At-Tirmidhi said: "Hasan Sahih." And he (peace be upon him) said: "Indeed, Allah questions the servant (Al-'Abd) until He says to him: 'What prevented you when you saw evil (Al-Munkar) from forbidding it?' When Allah provides the servant (Al-'Abd) with his excuse, he says: 'O Lord, I hoped in You and feared people.'" The hadith: "Allah questions the servant (Al-'Abd) until He says: 'What prevented you when you saw evil (Al-Munkar) in the world from forbidding it?'" The hadith was reported by Ibn Majah from the narration of Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri with a good chain. And this is when he fears from beating or something unbearable, and knowing the limits of that is problematic and contains danger. And in seclusion (Al-'Uzlah) is salvation. And in enjoining good (Al-Amr bil-Ma'ruf) and forbidding evil (An-Nahy 'anil-Munkar) is the stirring of disputes and the agitation of the depths of chests (Sudur), as it is said: 'And how many times have I driven in your traces from advice?' And the advisor (Al-Munassih) may gain hatred. And whoever tries enjoining good (Al-Amr bil-Ma'ruf) regrets it mostly, for it is like a leaning wall that a person wants to straighten, and it is about to fall upon him. When it falls upon him, he says: 'I wish I had left it leaning.' Yes, if he found helpers who held the wall until he secured it with a support, it would stand straight. And you today do not find the helpers, so leave them and save yourself (Nafsak)."

Vol 2: Enjoining Good and Forbidding Evil
Its interpretation: O you who have believed, upon you are your own selves (Anfusikum). The hadith was reported by the compilers of the Sunan and preceded in the chapter on seclusion. And I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, say: 'There is no people who commit sins while among them is one who is able to forbid them but does not do so, except that Allah is about to encompass them with punishment from Himself.' And it is narrated from Abu Tha'labah al-Khushani that he asked the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, about the interpretation of His saying, the Exalted: 'No harm will come to you from one who goes astray if you are guided.' The hadith of Abu Tha'labah that he asked the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, about the interpretation of His saying, the Exalted: 'No harm will come to you from one who goes astray if you are guided.' The hadith was reported by Abu Dawud, al-Tirmidhi who graded it as good, and Ibn Majah. So he said: 'O Abu Tha'labah, enjoin what is good (Ma'ruf) and forbid what is evil (Munkar). But when you see stinginess obeyed, desire (Hawa) followed, the worldly life preferred, and every possessor of an opinion admiring his own opinion, then upon you is your own self (Nafs) and leave the common people. Indeed, behind you are trials like pieces of a dark night; for the one who holds fast in them to something like what you are upon, there is the reward of fifty of you.' It was said: 'Rather from them, O Messenger of Allah?' He said: 'No, rather from you, because you find helpers for good and they do not find helpers for it.' And Ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, was asked about the interpretation of this verse. He said: 'This is not its time; today it is accepted. But it is about to come a time when you will enjoin what is good (Ma'ruf) and such and such will be done to you, and you will say, but it will not be accepted from you. Then at that time, upon you are your own selves (Anfusikum); no harm will come to you from one who goes astray if you are guided.'

Vol 2: Enjoining Good and Forbidding Evil
And as for the narrations, among them is what was narrated from Abu Bakr al-Siddiq (may Allah be pleased with him) that he said in a sermon he delivered: 'O people, you recite this verse and interpret it contrary to its interpretation: "O you who have believed, upon you is your own selves (Anfusakum). He who has strayed will not harm you when you have been guided." (Quran 5:105)' The narration of Abu Bakr: 'O people, you recite this verse and interpret it contrary to its interpretation: "O you who have believed, upon you is your own selves (Anfusakum)."' The narration was reported by the compilers of the Sunan and was previously mentioned in the chapter on seclusion (al-'Uzlah). And I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) say: 'There is no people who commit sins while among them is one who is able to forbid them (from it) but does not do so, except that Allah is about to encompass them with punishment from Himself.' And it was narrated from Abu Tha'labah al-Khushani that he asked the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) about the interpretation of His saying, the Exalted: "He who has strayed will not harm you when you have been guided." The narration of Abu Tha'labah: that he asked the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) about the interpretation of His saying, the Exalted: "He who has strayed will not harm you when you have been guided." The narration was reported by Abu Dawud, al-Tirmidhi (who graded it as good), and Ibn Majah. So he said: 'O Abu Tha'labah, enjoin the recognized good (al-Ma'ruf) and forbid the disapproved evil (al-Munkar). But if you see stinginess (Shuhh) being obeyed, desire (Hawa) being followed, worldly life (Dunya) being given preference, and every possessor of an opinion being impressed with his own opinion, then upon you is your own self (Nafs) and leave the common people. Indeed, behind you are trials (Fitna) like pieces of the dark night. For the one who holds fast therein to something like what you are upon, there is the reward of fifty of you.' It was said: 'Or of them, O Messenger of Allah?' He said: 'No, rather of you, because you find helpers upon the good (al-Khayr) and they do not find helpers upon it.' And Ibn Mas'ud (may Allah be pleased with him) was asked about the interpretation of this verse, so he said: 'This is not its time; today it is accepted. But it has almost come that its time will come: you will enjoin the recognized good (al-Ma'ruf) and such and such will be done to you, and you will say, but it will not be accepted from you. Then at that time, upon you is your own self (Nafs). He who has strayed will not harm you when you have been guided.'

a.g: O you who have believed, testimony [should be taken] among you when death approaches one of you at the time of bequest - [that of] two just men from among you or two others from outside if you are traveling through the land and the disaster of death should strike you. Detain them after the prayer and let them both swear by Allah if you doubt [their testimony, saying], "We will not exchange our oath for a price, even if he should be a near relative, and we will not withhold the testimony of Allah. Indeed, we would then be of the sinful."

But if it is found that those two were guilty of perjury, let two others stand in their place [who are] foremost [in claim] from those who have a lawful right. And let them swear by Allah, "Our testimony is truer than their testimony, and we have not transgressed. Indeed, we would then be of the wrongdoers."

That is more likely that they will give testimony according to its [true] objective, or [at least] they would fear that [other] oaths might be taken after their oaths. And fear Allah and listen; and Allah does not guide the defiantly disobedient people.

And at that time, Allah the Exalted will fulfill His saying: 'So We will surely question those to whom messengers were sent, and We will surely question the messengers. Then We will surely relate to them with knowledge, and We were not absent.' And His saying: 'So by your Lord, We will surely question them all about what they used to do.' Indeed, it is You who is Knower of the unseen."' So, what severity of a day in which the intellects (Aql) of the prophets are bewildered and their knowledges (Ilm) are erased from the intensity of the awe (Hiba) when it is said to them, 'What response did you receive?' And they had been sent to the creatures and they had known. So their intellects (Aql) are stunned, and they do not know with what to answer. So they say from the intensity of the awe (Hiba), 'We have no knowledge. Indeed, it is You who is Knower of the unseen.' And they at that time are truthful, for their intellects (Aql) have flown away and their knowledges (Ilm) have been erased until Allah the Exalted strengthens them.

And whoever knows the reality of knowledge (Ma'rifah) recognizes the deficiency of his knowledge in encompassing the essence of matters, his fear inevitably increases. Therefore, Jesus (peace be upon him) said when it was said to him: 'Did you say to people, "Take me and my mother as two gods besides Allah?" He said, "Glory be to You! It is not for me to say what I have no right to. If I had said it, You would have known it. You know what is within myself, and I do not know what is within Yourself."' And he said: 'If You punish them, indeed they are Your servants; and if You forgive them...' the verse. He delegated the matter to the Will (Mashiyyah) and completely removed himself from the affair, knowing that he has no part in the matter and that matters are connected to the Will in a connection that goes beyond the limits of rational considerations and familiar patterns. Thus, it is not possible to judge them by analogy, conjecture, or calculation, let alone by verification and certainty. This is what has broken the hearts of the knowers (Arifin), for the greatest calamity is the connection of your affair to the Will of One who does not care about you. ğŸ“– Vol 4: Poverty and Abstinence
Explanation of the virtue specifically of the poor who are content (Ar-Radhin), satisfied (Al-Qani'in), and truthful (As-Sadiqin). The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: 'Blessed is the one who is guided to Islam and whose livelihood is sufficient (Kafafan) and he is satisfied (Qana'a) with it' [36]. And he (peace be upon him) said: 'O community of the poor, give Allah contentment (Ar-Rida) from your hearts so you may attain the reward of your poverty, otherwise not' [37]. The first is the satisfied one (Al-Qani'), and this is the content one (Ar-Radi), and this almost indicates by its implication: that the greedy one has no reward for his poverty, but the general texts that have come regarding the virtue of poverty indicate that he has a reward as will be clarified later. Perhaps what is meant by lack of contentment (Ar-Rida) is dislike for Allah's action in withholding the world from him, and perhaps one desirous of wealth does not have denial of Allah the Exalted or dislike for His action occur in his heart, so that dislike is what nullifies the reward of poverty. And it is narrated from Umar ibn Al-Khattab (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (peace be upon him) that he said: 'Indeed everything has a key, and the key to Paradise is love for the destitute and the poor due to their patience (Sabr), they are the companions (Julusa') of Allah the Exalted on the Day of Resurrection' [38]. And it is narrated from Ali (may Allah honor his face) from the Prophet (peace be upon him) that he said: 'The most beloved of servants to Allah the Exalted is the poor one who is satisfied (Al-Qani') with his provision, content (Ar-Radi) with Allah the Exalted' [39]. And he (peace be upon him) said: 'O Allah, make the sustenance of the family of Muhammad sufficient (Kafafan)' [40]. And Allah the Exalted said: 'Allah said: "This is the Day when the truthful (As-Sadiqin) will benefit from their truthfulness (Sidq). For them are gardens beneath which rivers flow, wherein they will abide forever. Allah is pleased with them and they are pleased with Him. That is the great attainment."' [41]. So the truthful ones (As-Sadiqun) are those who were truthful in their poverty, patience (Sabr), and contentment (Rida), so their poverty was truthful not false, and their contentment (Rida) was truthful not forced, so they were among the people of this verse. Look how Allah the Exalted combined for them between truthfulness (Sidq) and contentment (Rida), saying: 'will benefit the truthful (As-Sadiqin) from their truthfulness (Sidq)' then said: 'Allah is pleased with them and they are pleased with Him', so He combined for them between the attribute of truthfulness (Sidq) and the attribute of contentment (Rida), and they are among the greatest attributes of the righteous poor. So whoever is truthful in his poverty and content (Radi) with the decree of Allah the Exalted, he is among those who will benefit from their truthfulness (Sidq) on the Day of Resurrection, and enters into the saying of Allah the Exalted: 'That is the great attainment.'

The First Foundation: The knowledge that the Maker of the world is Powerful (Qadir) and that He, exalted is He, in His saying 'And He is over all things Powerful (Qadir)' is truthful because the world is precise in its making, ordered in its creation. And whoever sees a garment of brocade, beautiful in its weaving and composition, harmonious in its embroidery and ornamentation, then imagines that its weaving issued from a dead thing that has no capability or from a human that has no power, has been stripped from the instinct of intellect and has been enrolled in the ranks of the people of stupidity and ignorance.
